member.name: T:Midi.Scale
member.summary: A scale based on a particular tonic.

remarks.para: For our purposes, a scale is defined by a tonic and then the pattern that it uses to ascend up to the next tonic and then descend back to the original tonic. The tonic is described with a because it is not specific to any one octave. The ascending/descending pattern is provided by the nested class.
This class comes with a collection of predefined patterns, such as Scale.Major and Scale.HarmonicMinor.

member.name: M:Midi.Scale.#ctor(Midi.NoteFamily,Midi.Scale.Pattern)
member.summary: Constructs a scale from its tonic and its pattern.

member.name: M:Midi.Scale.Traverse(Midi.Note,Midi.Note)
member.summary: Returns the sequence of notes generated by this scale when moving from start to finish.
member.param: The first note in the traversal.
The last note in the traversal.
member.returns: The sequence of notes. The result always includes start and finish, and then includes whichever intervening notes are implied by scale when moving in that direction.

member.name: M:Midi.Scale.ContainsWhenAscending(Midi.Note)
member.summary: Returns true if note would be in this scale when ascending through the note.
member.returns: True if note is included when ascending.

member.name: M:Midi.Scale.ContainsWhenDescending(Midi.Note)
member.summary: Returns true if note would be in this scale when decending through the note.
member.returns: True if note is included when decending.

member.name: F:Midi.Scale.Patterns
member.summary: Array of all the built-in scale patterns.

member.name: M:Midi.Scale.ComputeMasks
member.summary: Fills ascendingMask and descendingMask based on ascendingDescendingPattern.
member.returns: True if the operation succeeded, false if the pattern was invalid.

member.name: P:Midi.Scale.AscendingNotes
member.summary: The ascending sequence of notes in this scale.

member.name: P:Midi.Scale.DescendingNotes
member.summary: The descending sequence of notes in this scale.

member.name: T:Midi.Scale.Pattern
member.summary: Description of a scale's ascending/descending pattern through an octave.
member.remarks: This class describes the general behavior of a scale as it ascends from a tonic up to the next tonic and back down again. It is described in terms of semitones relative to the tonic; to apply it to particular tonic, pass one of these to the constructor of .

member.name: M:Midi.Scale.Pattern.#ctor(System.String,System.Int32[])
member.param: The name of the scale pattern.
Array encoding the behavior of the scale as it ascends from the tonic up to the next tonic and back. This must satisfy the requirements of .

member.name: M:Midi.Scale.Pattern.IsSequenceValid(System.Int32[])
member.summary: Returns true if the specified sequence is valid.
member.param: The sequence to test. The first element must be 0, to indicate beginning at the tonic. Then there must be a monotonically increasing sequence of notes, given in semitones-above-the-tonic. Then there must be a 12, to indicate arrival at the tonic above. Then there must be a monotonically decreasing sequence of notes, given in semitones-above-the-tonic. The last element must be 0, to indicate arrival back at the original tonic.
member.returns: True if the sequence is valid, false otherwise.

member.name: P:Midi.Scale.Pattern.Name
member.summary: The name of the scale being described.

member.name: P:Midi.Scale.Pattern.SemitoneSequence
member.summary: The ascending/descending sequence of the scale, given in the constructor.

member.name: T:Midi.CallbackMessage
member.summary: Pseudo-MIDI message used to arrange for a callback at a certain time.

remarks.para: This message can be scheduled with Clock.Schedule just like any other message. When its time comes and it gets "sent", it invokes the callback provided in the constructor.
The idea is that you can embed callback points into the music you've scheduled, so that (if the clock gets to that point in the music) your code has an opportunity for some additional processing.
The callback is invoked on the MidiOutputDevice's worker thread.

member.name: M:Midi.CallbackMessage.#ctor(Midi.CallbackMessage.CallbackType,System.Single)
member.param: The callback to invoke when this message is "sent".

member.name: M:Midi.CallbackMessage.SendNow
member.summary: Sends this message immediately, ignoring the beatTime.
member.returns: Additional messages which should be scheduled as a result of this message, or null.

member.name: M:Midi.CallbackMessage.MakeTimeShiftedCopy(System.Single)
member.summary: Returns a copy of this message, shifted in time by the specified amount.

member.name: P:Midi.CallbackMessage.Callback
member.summary: The callback to invoke when this message is "sent".

member.name: T:Midi.CallbackMessage.CallbackType
member.summary: Delegate called when a CallbackMessage is sent.
member.param: The time at which this event was scheduled.
member.returns: Additional messages which should be scheduled as a result of this callback, or null.

members.member:
Common base class for input and output devices.
This base class exists mainly so that input and output devices can both go into the same kinds of MidiMessages.

member.name: T:Midi.DeviceException
member.summary: Exception thrown when an operation on a MIDI device cannot be satisfied.

member.name: M:Midi.DeviceException.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Constructs exception with a specific error message.

remarks.para: A chord is defined by its root note, the chord pattern, and the inversion. The root note is described with a because we want to be able to talk about the chord independent of any one octave. The pattern is given by the nested class. The inversion is an integer indicating how many rotations the pattern has undergone.
This class comes with a collection of predefined chord patterns, such as and .

member.name: M:Midi.Chord.#ctor(Midi.NoteFamily,Midi.Chord.Pattern,System.Int32)
member.summary: Constructs a chord from its root note, pattern, and inversion.
member.param: The root note of the chord.
The inversion, in [0..N-1] where N is the number of notes in pattern.
member.exception: root is invalid or inversion is out of range.

member.name: M:Midi.Chord.InvertSequence(System.Int32[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns an inverted copy of semitoneSequence (or the original if inversion = 0).

member.name: M:Midi.Chord.FindMatchingChords(System.Collections.Generic.List{Midi.Note})
member.summary: Returns a list of chords which match the set of input notes.
member.returns: A (possibly empty) list of chords.

member.name: F:Midi.Chord.Patterns
member.summary: Array of all the built-in chord patterns.

member.name: P:Midi.Chord.Root
member.summary: The root note of the chord.

member.name: P:Midi.Chord.Bass
member.summary: The bass note of the chord.

member.name: P:Midi.Chord.Notes
member.summary: The sequence of notes in this chord.
member.remarks: The result is in terms of note families (ie, not octave-specific). The order in the result is based on the inversion, so the root note may not come first.

member.name: T:Midi.Chord.Pattern
member.summary: Description of a chord's pattern starting at the root note.
member.remarks: This class describes the ascending sequence of notes included in a chord, starting with the root note. It is described in terms of semitones relative to root; to apply it to particular tonic, pass one of these to the constructor of .

member.name: M:Midi.Chord.Pattern.#ctor(System.String,System.String,System.Int32[])
member.param: The shorthand for the chord. This is the string used in the abbreviated name for a chord, placed immediately after the tonic and before the slashed inversion (if there is one).
Array encoding the notes in the chord. This must satisfy the requirements of .

member.name: M:Midi.Chord.Pattern.IsSequenceValid(System.Int32[])
member.summary: Returns true if the given sequence is valid.
member.param: The sequence to test. The first element must be 0, to indicate beginning at the root note. Then there must be a monotonically increasing sequence of notes, given in semitones-above-the-root.
member.returns: True if the sequence is valid, false otherwise.

member.name: P:Midi.Chord.Pattern.Name
member.summary: The name of the chord being described.

member.name: P:Midi.Chord.Pattern.Shorthand
member.summary: Shorthand string for this chord pattern.
member.remarks: This is the string used in the abbreviated name for a chord, placed immediately after the tonic and before the slashed inversion (if there is one).

member.name: P:Midi.Chord.Pattern.SemitoneSequence
member.summary: The ascending note sequence of the chord, in semitones-above-the-root.

member.name: T:Midi.Instrument
member.summary: General MIDI instrument, used in Program Change messages.

remarks.para: The MIDI protocol defines a Program Change message, which can be used to switch a device among "presets". The General MIDI specification further standardizes those presets into the specific instruments in this enum. General-MIDI-compliant devices will have these particular instruments; non-GM devices may have other instruments.
MIDI instruments are one-indexed in the spec, but they're zero-indexed in code, so we have them zero-indexed here.
This enum has extension methods, such as and , defined in .

member.name: T:Midi.InstrumentExtensionMethods
member.summary: Extension methods for the Instrument enum.

member.name: M:Midi.InstrumentExtensionMethods.Validate(Midi.Instrument)
member.summary: Throws an exception if instrument is not valid.

member.name: F:Midi.InstrumentExtensionMethods.InstrumentNames
member.summary: General Midi instrument names, used by GetInstrumentName().

member.name: M:Midi.InstrumentExtensionMethods.Name(Midi.Instrument)
member.summary: Returns the human-readable name of a MIDI instrument.

members.member:
A time-sorted queue of MIDI messages.
Messages can be added in any order, and can be popped off in timestamp order.

Adds a message to the queue.
The message to add to the queue. The message must have a valid timestamp (not MidiMessage.Now), but other than that there is no restriction on the timestamp. For example, it is legal to add a message with a timestamp earlier than some other message which was previously removed from the queue. Such a message would become the new "earliest" message, and so would be be the first message returned by PopEarliest().

member.name: M:Midi.MessageQueue.Clear
member.summary: Discards all messages in the queue.

member.name: M:Midi.MessageQueue.PopEarliest
member.summary: Removes and returns the message(s) in the queue that have the earliest timestamp.

member.name: P:Midi.MessageQueue.IsEmpty
member.summary: True if the queue is empty.

members.member:
The timestamp of the earliest messsage(s) in the queue.
Throws an exception if the queue is empty.

remarks.para: In General MIDI, notes played on make the following percussion sounds, regardless of any Program Change messages on that channel.
This enum is used with OutputDevice.SendPercussion and . Equivalently, when cast to it can be used with OutputDevice.SendNoteOn and on .
This enum has extension methods, such as and , defined in .

members.member:
Extension methods for the Percussion enum.
Be sure to "using midi" if you want to use these as extension methods.

member.name: M:Midi.PercussionExtensionMethods.IsValid(Midi.Percussion)
member.summary: Returns true if the specified percussion is valid.

member.name: M:Midi.PercussionExtensionMethods.Validate(Midi.Percussion)
member.summary: Throws an exception if percussion is not valid.

member.name: M:Midi.PercussionExtensionMethods.Name(Midi.Percussion)
member.summary: Returns the human-readable name of a MIDI percussion.

remarks.para: MIDI defines 127 distinct notes, in semitone intervals, ranging from C five octaves below middle C, up to G five octaves above middle C. This covers several octaves above and below the range of a normal 88-key piano.

These 127 notes are the only ones directly expressible in MIDI. Precise variations in frequency can be achieved with Pitch Bend messages, though Pitch Bend messages apply to the whole channel at once.

In this enum, each note name includes the letter name, followed by Sharp if necessary, followed by the octave number, where octaves are numbered with standard piano terminology: Middle C is in octave four. Thus octaves range from -1 to 9. (This is different from "MIDI octaves", which range from -5 to 5.)
This enum has extension methods, such as and , defined in .

member.name: F:Midi.Note.ASharp0
member.summary: A# in octave 0, usually the lowest key on an 88-key keyboard.

member.name: F:Midi.Note.C4
member.summary: C in octave 4, also known as Middle C.

member.name: F:Midi.Note.C8
member.summary: C in octave 8, usually the highest key on an 88-key keyboard.

member.name: T:Midi.NoteExtensionMethods
member.summary: Extension methods for the Note enum.

member.name: M:Midi.NoteExtensionMethods.IsValid(Midi.Note)
member.summary: Returns true if note is valid.
member.returns: True if the note is valid.

member.name: M:Midi.NoteExtensionMethods.Validate(Midi.Note)
member.summary: Throws an exception if note is invalid.

member.name: M:Midi.NoteExtensionMethods.Octave(Midi.Note)
member.summary: Returns the octave number of the given note.
member.returns: The octave. For example, "C4"'s octave is 4.

member.name: M:Midi.NoteExtensionMethods.Name(Midi.Note)
member.summary: Returns the name of the specified note.
member.returns: The note's name. For example, note 60 is "C4", and note 61 is "C#4".

member.name: M:Midi.NoteExtensionMethods.Family(Midi.Note)
member.summary: Returns the family of the specified note.
member.returns: The note's family. For example, C4's family is C.

member.name: M:Midi.NoteExtensionMethods.SemitonesAbove(Midi.Note,Midi.NoteFamily)
member.summary: Returns the number of semitones that note is above tonic.
member.returns: The number of semitones, always in [0..11].

remarks.para: A note's "family" is simply the note's name without regard to the specific octave. So, for example, CSharp3, CSharp4, and CSharp5 are all part of the CSharp note family. This enum lets us talk about the function or role of a note independent of the particular octave.
This enum has extension methods, such as and , defined in .

member.name: T:Midi.NoteFamilyExtensionMethods
member.summary: Extension methods for the NoteFamily enum.

member.name: M:Midi.NoteFamilyExtensionMethods.IsValid(Midi.NoteFamily)
member.summary: Returns true if the specified note family is valid.

member.name: M:Midi.NoteFamilyExtensionMethods.Wrapped(Midi.NoteFamily)
member.summary: Returns a copy of family which is made valid by wrapping if necessary.
member.returns: The wrapped copy of family.

member.name: M:Midi.NoteFamilyExtensionMethods.Validate(Midi.NoteFamily)
member.summary: Throws an exception if family is not valid.

member.name: M:Midi.NoteFamilyExtensionMethods.Name(Midi.NoteFamily)
member.summary: Returns the human-readable name of a note family.

remarks.para: Each instance of this class describes a MIDI output device installed on the system. You cannot create your own instances, but instead must go through the property to find which devices are available. You may wish to examine the property of each one and present the user with a choice of which device to use.
Open an output device with and close it with . While it is open, you may send MIDI messages with functions such as , and . All notes may be silenced on the device by calling .

Note that the above methods send their messages immediately. If you wish to arrange for a message to be sent at a specific future time, you'll need to instantiate some subclass of (eg ) and then pass it to Clock.Schedule.

member.name: M:Midi.OutputDevice.SilenceAllNotes
member.summary: Silences all notes on this output device.

member.name: M:Midi.OutputDevice.SendNoteOn(Midi.Channel,Midi.Note,System.Int32)
member.summary: Sends a Note On message to this MIDI output device.
member.exception: channel, note, or velocity is out-of-range.

member.name: M:Midi.OutputDevice.SendNoteOff(Midi.Channel,Midi.Note,System.Int32)
member.summary: Sends a Note Off message to this MIDI output device.
member.exception: channel, note, or velocity is out-of-range.

member.name: M:Midi.OutputDevice.SendPercussion(Midi.Percussion,System.Int32)
member.summary: Sends a Note On message to Channel10 of this MIDI output device.
member.remarks: This is simply shorthand for a Note On message on Channel10 with a percussion-specific note, so there is no corresponding message to receive from an input device.

member.name: M:Midi.OutputDevice.SendControlChange(Midi.Channel,Midi.Control,System.Int32)
member.summary: Sends a Control Change message to this MIDI output device.
member.exception: channel, control, or value is out-of-range.

member.name: M:Midi.OutputDevice.SendPitchBend(Midi.Channel,System.Int32)
member.summary: Sends a Pitch Bend message to this MIDI output device.
member.param: The pitch bend value, 0..16383, 8192 is centered.

member.name: M:Midi.OutputDevice.SendProgramChange(Midi.Channel,Midi.Instrument)
member.summary: Sends a Program Change message to this MIDI output device.
member.remarks: A Program Change message is used to switch among instrument settings, generally instrument voices. An instrument conforming to General Midi 1 will have the instruments described in the enum; other instruments may have different instrument sets.

member.name: M:Midi.OutputDevice.CheckReturnCode(Midi.Win32API.MMRESULT)
member.summary: Makes sure rc is MidiWin32Wrapper.MMSYSERR_NOERROR. If not, throws an exception with an appropriate error message.

member.name: M:Midi.OutputDevice.CheckOpen
member.summary: Throws a MidiDeviceException if this device is not open.

member.name: M:Midi.OutputDevice.CheckNotOpen
member.summary: Throws a MidiDeviceException if this device is open.

member.name: M:Midi.OutputDevice.#ctor(System.UIntPtr,Midi.Win32API.MIDIOUTCAPS)
member.summary: Private Constructor, only called by the getter for the InstalledDevices property.
member.param: Position of this device in the list of all devices.

member.name: M:Midi.OutputDevice.MakeDeviceList
member.summary: Private method for constructing the array of MidiOutputDevices by calling the Win32 api.

member.name: P:Midi.OutputDevice.InstalledDevices
member.summary: List of devices installed on this system.

member.name: P:Midi.OutputDevice.IsOpen
member.summary: True if this device is open.

member.name: T:Midi.Control
member.summary: MIDI Control, used in Control Change messages.

remarks.para: In MIDI, Control Change messages are used to influence various auxiliary "controls" on a device, such as knobs, levers, and pedals. Controls are specified with integers in [0..127]. This enum provides an incomplete list of controls, because most controls are too obscure to document effetively here. Even for the ones listed here, the details of how the value is interpreted are arcane. Please see the MIDI spec for details.
The most commonly used control is SustainPedal, which is considered off when < 64, on when > 64.
This enum has extension methods, such as and , defined in .

members.member:
C# wrappers for the Win32 MIDI API.
Because .NET does not provide MIDI support itself, in C# we must use P/Invoke to wrap the Win32 API. That API consists of the MMSystem.h C header and the winmm.dll library. The API is described in detail here: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms712733(VS.85).aspx. The P/Invoke interop mechanism is described here: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/aa288468(VS.71).aspx.
This file covers the subset of the MIDI protocol needed to manage input and output devices and send and receive Note On/Off, Control Change, Pitch Bend and Program Change messages. Other portions of the MIDI protocol (such as sysex events) are supported in the Win32 API but are not wrapped here.
Some of the C functions are not typesafe when wrapped, so those wrappers are made private and typesafe variants are provided.

member.name: F:Midi.Win32API.MAXPNAMELEN
member.summary: Max length of a manufacturer name in the Win32 API.

member.name: T:Midi.Interval
member.summary: Interval measuring the relationship between pitches.

remarks.para: This enum is simply for making interval operations more explicit. When adding to or subtracting from the enum, one can either use ints...
...or use the Interval enum, cast to int...
These two examples are equivalent. The benefit of the latter is simply that it makes the intention more explicit.
This enum has extension methods, such as , defined in .

member.name: T:Midi.IntervalExtensionMethods
member.summary: Extension methods for the Interval enum.

member.name: M:Midi.IntervalExtensionMethods.Name(Midi.Interval)
member.summary: Returns the human-readable name of an interval.
member.returns: The human-readable name. If the interval is less than an octave, it gives the standard term (eg, "Major third"). If the interval is more than an octave, it gives the number of semitones in the interval.

remarks.para: Each instance of this class describes a MIDI input device installed on the system. You cannot create your own instances, but instead must go through the property to find which devices are available. You may wish to examine the property of each one and present the user with a choice of which device(s) to use.

Open an input device with and close it with . While it is open, you may arrange to start receiving messages with and then stop receiving them with . An input device can only receive messages when it is both open and started.
Incoming messages are routed to the corresponding events, such as and . The event handlers are invoked on a background thread which is started in and stopped in .

As each message is received, it is assigned a timestamp in one of two ways. If is called with a , then each message is assigned a time by querying the clock's property. If is called with null, then each message is assigned a time based on the number of seconds since was called.

member.name: M:Midi.InputDevice.Open
member.remarks: Note that Open() establishes a connection to the device, but no messages will be received until is called.

member.name: M:Midi.InputDevice.Close
member.exception: The device is not open or is still receiving.

member.name: M:Midi.InputDevice.StartReceiving(Midi.Clock)
member.summary: Starts this input device receiving messages.
member.param: If non-null, the clock's property will be used to assign a timestamp to each incoming message. If null, timestamps will be in seconds since StartReceiving() was called.
member.exception: The device is not open or is already receiving.

remarks.para: This method launches a background thread to listen for input events, and as events are received, the event handlers are invoked on that background thread. Event handlers should be written to work from a background thread. (For example, if they want to update the GUI, they may need to BeginInvoke to arrange for GUI updates to happen on the correct thread.)
The background thread which is created by this method is joined (shut down) in .

member.name: M:Midi.InputDevice.StopReceiving
member.summary: Stops this input device from receiving messages.

remarks.para: This method waits for all in-progress input event handlers to finish, and then joins (shuts down) the background thread that was created in . Thus, when this function returns you can be sure that no more event handlers will be invoked.

It is illegal to call this method from an input event handler (ie, from the background thread), and doing so throws an exception. If an event handler really needs to call this method, consider using BeginInvoke to schedule it on another thread.

member.exception: The device is not open; is not receiving; or called from within an event handler (ie, from the background thread).

member.name: M:Midi.InputDevice.CheckReturnCode(Midi.Win32API.MMRESULT)
member.summary: Makes sure rc is MidiWin32Wrapper.MMSYSERR_NOERROR. If not, throws an exception with an appropriate error message.

remarks.para: Each MIDI device has 16 independent channels. Channels are named starting at 1, but are encoded programmatically starting at 0.

All of the channels are general-purpose except for Channel10, which is the dedicated percussion channel. Any notes sent to that channel will play percussion notes, regardless of any Program Change messages sent on that channel.
This enum has extension methods, such as and , defined in .

member.name: F:Midi.Channel.Channel10
member.summary: MIDI Channel 10, the dedicated percussion channel.

member.summary: Extension methods for the Channel enum.

member.summary: Returns true if the specified channel is valid.

member.summary: Throws an exception if channel is not valid.

member.name: M:Midi.ChannelExtensionMethods.Name(Midi.Channel)
member.summary: Returns the human-readable name of a MIDI channel.

member.name: T:Midi.Clock
member.summary: A clock for scheduling MIDI messages in a rate-adjustable, pausable timeline.

remarks.para: Clock is used for scheduling MIDI messages. Though you can always send messages synchronously with the various .Send* methods, doing so requires your code to be "ready" at the precise moment each message needs to be sent. In most cases, and especially in interactive programs, it's more convenient to describe messages that will be sent at specified points in the future, and then rely on a scheduler to make it happen. Clock is such a scheduler.

In the simplest case, Clock can be used to schedule a sequence of messages which is known in its entirety ahead of time. For example, this code snippet schedules two notes to play one after the other:

At this point, four messages have been scheduled, but they haven't been sent because the clock has not started. We can start the clock with , pause it with , and reset it with . We can change the beats-per-minute at any time, even as the sequence is playing. And the playing happens in a background thread, so your client code can focus on arranging the notes and controlling the clock.

You can even schedule new notes as the clock is playing. Generally you should schedule messages for times in the future; scheduling a message with a time in the past simply causes it to play immediately, which is probably not what you wanted.

In the above example, we wanted to play two notes but had to schedule four messages. This case is so common that we provide a convenience class, , which encapsulates a Note On message and its corresponding Note Off message in a single unit. We could rewrite the above example as follows:

This works because each NoteOnOffMessage, when it is actually sent, does two things: it sends the Note On message to the output device, and also schedules the correponding Note Off message for the appropriate time in the future. This is an example of a self-propagating message: a message which, when triggered, schedules additional events for the future.

You can design your own self-propagating messages by subclassing from . For example, you could make a self-propagating MetronomeMessage which keeps a steady beat by always scheduling the next MetronomeMessage when it plays the current beat. However, subclassing can be tedious, and it is usually preferable to use to call-out to your own code instead.

member.name: M:Midi.Clock.#ctor(System.Single)
member.summary: Constructs a midi clock with a given beats-per-minute.
member.param: The initial beats-per-minute, which can be changed later.

remarks.para: When constructed, the clock is not running, and so will return zero. Call when you are ready for the clock to start progressing (and scheduled messages to actually trigger).
This method causes the clock to start progressing at the rate given in the property. It may only be called when the clock is not yet rnuning.

If this is the first time Start is called, the clock starts at time zero and progresses from there. If the clock was previously started, stopped, and not reset, then Start effectively "unpauses" the clock, picking up at the left-off time, and resuming scheduling of any as-yet-unsent messages.
This method creates a new thread which runs in the background and sends messages at the appropriate times. All Message.SendNow methods and s will be called in that thread.
The scheduler thread is joined (shut down) in .

member.name: M:Midi.Clock.Stop
member.summary: Stops the clock (but does not reset its time or discard pending events).

remarks.para: This method stops the progression of the clock. It may only be called when the clock is running.
Any scheduled but as-yet-unsent messages remain in the queue. A consecutive call to can re-start the progress of the clock, or can discard pending messages and reset the clock to zero.

This method waits for any in-progress messages to be processed and joins (shuts down) the scheduler thread before returning, so when it returns you can be sure that no more messages will be sent or callbacks invoked.

It is illegal to call Stop from the scheduler thread (ie, from any Message.SendNow method or . If a callback really needs to stop the clock, consider using BeginInvoke to arrange for it to happen in another thread.

member.exception: Clock is not running or Stop was invoked from the scheduler thread.

member.name: M:Midi.Clock.Reset
member.summary: Resets the clock to zero and discards pending messages.

remarks.para: This method resets the clock to zero and discards any scheduled but as-yet-unsent messages. It may only be called when the clock is not running.

member.name: M:Midi.Clock.Schedule(Midi.Message)
member.summary: Schedules a single message based on its beatTime.

remarks.para: This method schedules a message to be sent at the time indicated in the message's property. It may be called at any time, whether the clock is running or not. The message will not be sent until the clock progresses to the specified time. (If the clock is never started, or is paused before that time and not re-started, then the message will never be sent.)
If a message is scheduled for a time that has already passed, then the scheduler will send the message at the first opportunity.

member.name: M:Midi.Clock.Schedule(System.Collections.Generic.List{Midi.Message},System.Single)
member.summary: Schedules a collection of messages, applying an optional time delta to the scheduled beatTime.

member.name: M:Midi.Clock.MillisecondsUntil(System.Single)
member.summary: Returns the number of milliseconds from now until the specified beat time.
member.returns: The positive number of milliseconds, or 0 if beatTime is in the past.

member.name: F:Midi.Clock.isSchedulerThread
member.summary: Thread-local, set to true in the scheduler thread, false in all other threads.

member.name: P:Midi.Clock.BeatTime
member.summary: This clock's current time in beats.

remarks.para: Normally, this method polls the clock's current time, and thus changes from moment to moment as long as the clock is running. However, when called from the scheduler thread (that is, from a Message.SendNow method or a ), it returns the precise time at which the message was scheduled.

For example, suppose a callback was scheduled for time T, and the scheduler managed to call that callback at time T+delta. In the callback, BeatTime will return T for the duration of the callback. In any other thread, BeatTime would return approximately T+delta.
Setting this property changes the rate at which the clock progresses. If the clock is currently running, the new rate is effectively immediately.

member.name: P:Midi.Clock.IsRunning
member.summary: Returns true if this clock is currently running.
